                    ### Question
                    A three year old child is brought to the emergency depament having just ingested a large overdose of an antihistaminic drug. This drug is a weak base capable of entering most tissues including the brain. On physical examination the hea rate is 100/ minute, blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 20/ minute. In this case of poisoning:

                    ### Options
                    opa. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent
opb. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NaHCO 3, an alkalinizing agent
opc. More of the drug would be ionized at blood pH than at stomach pH
opd. Absorption of the drug would be faster from the stomach than from the small intestine.

### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
In the case of a weak base antihistaminic drug overdose, urinary excretion can be accelerated by acidifying the urine. This is because weak bases become more ionized in acidic environments, reducing their reabsorption and increasing excretion. Therefore, administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent, would enhance excretion (Option A). Conversely, alkalinizing the urine with NaHCO3 would decrease ionization, increase reabsorption, and reduce excretion (Option B). Regarding ionization, weak bases are more ionized in acidic environments like the stomach, meaning more of the drug would be ionized at stomach pH than at blood pH (Option C). For absorption, weak bases are less absorbed in the acidic stomach and more absorbed in the more alkaline small intestine, making absorption faster in the small intestine (Option D). The retrieved evidence paths, while broad, confirm the interaction of histamine antagonists with body systems, supporting the understanding of drug behavior in different pH environments.
